reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s “value is multiplicative/product of factors” model used to motivate eutopian fragility and the skewed distribution/‘small target’ intuition. That model is an important support for Section 2’s core takeaway, but it is not the only pillar of the overall position (which also leans heavily on the later fussy-vs-easygoing value-function analysis, population-ethical considerations, and many concrete ‘single flaw’ examples). So centrality is moderate. On strength: it correctly notes that the product model presumes strong complementarity/non-substitutability across value dimensions; if instead value is additive or partially substitutable, then the specific product-of-independent-uniforms graph and “one flaw collapses total value” intuition no longer follows. However, the essay presents the multiplicative model as a toy/explanatory model (“one model is…”) rather than a fully necessary premise, and even under additive aggregation the essay’s broader ‘many ways to lose lots of value’ point can still hold (large weights, many dimensions, fat tails, etc.). So the critique weakens but does not overturn the argument. Correctness is fairly high, with some overstatement/mild mischaracterization in implying the paper’s fragility case largely “relies on” the multiplicative ontology. Clarity is high, dead weight is minimal, and it stays focused on a single issue.
title: Substitutable moral goods undermine the multiplicative fragility model
